action.action-desc: Mr. Kilmer (for himself, Mr. Palazzo, and Mr. Heck) introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on Armed Services

form.official-title: To amend title 10, United States Code, to provide for the establishment and operation of reserve component cyber civil support teams, and for other purposes.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Major General Tim Lowenberg National Guard Cyber Defenders Act.

section.header: Establishment and operation of reserve component cyber civil support teams

subsection.text: Section 12310(c) of title 10, United States Code, is amended—

paragraph.text: in paragraph (1), by adding at the end the following new subparagraph:

subparagraph.text: An attack or natural disaster impacting a computer, electronic, or cyber network.
by striking A Reserve may perform duty described in paragraph (1) and inserting (A) A Reserve may perform duty described in subparagraphs (A) through (D) of paragraph (1); and
by adding at the end the following new subparagraph:
A Reserve, including a Reserve assigned or attached to a reserve component cyber civil support team, may perform duty described in subparagraph (E) of paragraph (1).

subsection.text: Section 12310(c) of title 10, United States Code, is further amended—

paragraph.text: in the subsection heading, by striking and Terrorist Attacks and inserting , Terrorist Attacks, and Cyber Attacks; and
in paragraph (5), by striking weapons of mass destruction civil support team and inserting civil support team described in paragraph (3).

section.header: Prompt implementation of reserve component cyber civil support teams

subsection.text: Not later than September 30, 2022, each State, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, Guam, and the Virgin Islands shall have an operational reserve component cyber civil support team composed of reserve component members of the Armed Forces assigned under section 12310 of title 10, United States Code.
Not later than September 30, 2018, the Chief of the National Guard Bureau shall submit to Congress a report—

paragraph.text: identifying which States, and whether the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, Guam, and the Virgin Islands, have satisfied the requirement imposed by subsection (a);
establishing a plan for meeting the deadline imposed by subsection (a);
assessing the level of involvement and assistance of the National Guard Bureau in the establishment and support of reserve component cyber civil support teams; and
evaluating the need for increased levels of such involvement and assistance.

subsection.text: To be considered operational, a reserve component cyber civil support team must be ready—

paragraph.text: to perform duties relating to analysis and protection in support of responding to emergencies involving an attack or natural disaster impacting a computer, electronic, or cyber network;
to advise and coordinate on any incident deemed critical for the protection of life, property, and maintenance of good order for the Governor;
to cooperate with and assist private sector owners and operators of critical infrastructure and key resources;
to collaborate and participate in information sharing with Federal, State, and local Fusion Centers, emergency management authorities, and emergency management divisions; and
to maintain relationships and close coordination with—

subparagraph.text: State-based employees of the Protective Security Advisor Program Office of the Department of Homeland Security;
cybersecurity advisors of the Department of Homeland Security (where assigned); and
employees of the Office of Infrastructure Protection of the Department of Homeland Security.

subsection.text: To ensure standardization among reserve component cyber civil support teams, the National Guard Bureau Joint Staff shall provide program management and oversight as follows:

paragraph.text: Members of a reserve component cyber civil support team shall undergo initial training comprising a military occupational specialty or Air Force Specialty Code initial skills course approved by a branch of the Armed Forces.
The National Guard Bureau Joint Staff shall establish specific curricula for teams, which shall—

subparagraph.text: include best-of-breed commercially available training and a National Guard-developed course focused on domestic coordination, communication, and cyber incident response skills; and

be updated on a periodic basis based on the evolving circumstances of cyber threats, the needs of the public and private entities such teams support, and the relationships between such teams and such entities.

subsection.text: The National Guard Bureau Joint Staff shall consult with the Council of Governors and other appropriate civilian authorities to establish guidance to States concerning situations that are appropriate for the involvement of a reserve component cyber civil support team.
The National Guard Bureau Joint Staff may establish a minimum length of service for a member of a reserve component cyber civil support team.

section.text: The requirements of section 552 of title 5, United States Code, shall apply to any reserve component cyber civil support teams composed of reserve component members of the Armed Forces assigned under section 12310 of title 10, United States Code.
There is authorized to be appropriated to the Secretary of Defense $50,000,000 to implement this Act and the amendments made by this Act.
